docs.lead_paragraph: Attention, people over 65. Is your brain slowing down, your memory failing, your resistance to infection taking a nose dive? This is not an advertisement for a secret anti-aging formula, but a call to improve your nutrition. Too many older people may be accepting a cognitive and immunological decline as a normal part of aging, when it may reflect a deficiency in essential nutrients like vitamins and minerals. A simple one-a-day type supplement may be all that is needed to slow or even stem that decline, recent studies show.

headline.main: Nutrition a Key to Better Health for Elderly

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on improved nutrition as key to better health for elderly; holds cognitive and immunological decline accepted as normal part of aging may reflect deficiency in essential nutrients; cites Dr Ranjit Kumar Chandra's study showing nutrient supplement with modest amounts of 18 vitamins, minerals and trace elements improved cognitive function in apparently healthy people over 65; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Attention, people over 65. Is your brain slowing down, your memory failing, your resistance to infection taking a nose dive? This is not an advertisement for a secret anti-aging formula, but a call to improve your nutrition.    Too many older people...

docs.lead_paragraph: People with congestive heart failure do so much worse if they also suffer from major depression that they should routinely be given psychiatric assessments, a new study recommends. Researchers from Duke University, writing in the current Archives of Internal Medicine, said they found that seriously depressed heart-failure patients appeared twice as likely as other patients to die or be readmitted to the hospital over the course of a year.

headline.main: Treat the Mind and Help the Heart

docs.abstract: Study by Duke University researchers finds people with congestive heart failure do so much worse if they also suffer from major depression that heart failure patients should routinely be given psychiatric assessments; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: People with congestive heart failure do so much worse if they also suffer from major depression that they should routinely be given psychiatric assessments, a new study recommends.    Researchers from Duke University, writing in the current Archives...

docs.lead_paragraph: ACE inhibitors are among the most widely used drugs used to treat heart disease and high blood pressure. But despite their proven benefits, many patients find they cannot take them because they bring on a persistent dry cough. Now researchers believe that iron supplements may be the remedy. Writing in the current issue of Hypertension: Journal of the American Heart Association, scientists say it appears that small amounts of iron can suppress the cough.

headline.main: Iron May Soothe Heart Patients' Coughs

docs.abstract: Researchers report small amounts of iron supplement can suppress persistent dry cough experienced by many patients who take ACE inhibitors to treat heart disease and high blood pressure (S)
docs.snippet: ACE inhibitors are among the most widely used drugs used to treat heart disease and high blood pressure. But despite their proven benefits, many patients find they cannot take them because they bring on a persistent dry cough.    Now researchers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sidney Kleinman can't get a good night's sleep. The street can be still, the wind calm and the neighbors peaceful, but the racket and roar in Mr. Kleinman's head can become so loud that it jolts him out of the deepest slumber. There may as well be a block full of car alarms clanging through the night. ''It wakes me up like an alarm clock every hour and a half or so,'' said Mr. Kleinman, a 69-year-old lawyer in Chicago. ''In one ear I hear a sort of electronic pinging, like crickets chirping, and in the other I hear roaring.''

headline.main: Turning Down the Phantom Noise Inside the Head

docs.abstract: Tinnitus, odd neurochemical mix-up in brain, afflicts over 50 million Americans, causing them to hear phantom noises from time to time; some 20 percent of people with tinnitus find pinging or roaring is loud and frequent enough to bring life to halt; researchers are using imaging techniques to pinpoint regions of brain where phantom noises originate; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Call security!'' the emergency room physician ordered a nearby nurse. ''I'm not about to wrestle with a 17-year-old autistic boy.'' Within seconds, doors swung open and three bouncer-size men in dark uniforms and beige surgical gloves appeared, ready to pounce on my son.

headline.main: A Long Night In Dark Land Of Autism

docs.abstract: Annie Lubliner Lehmann Cases article on night spent in emergency room with 17-year-old autistic son experiencing unexplained panic attack

docs.lead_paragraph: ''On Doctoring,'' edited by Dr. Richard Reynolds and Dr. John Stone, Simon & Schuster, $35. Surgeons must be very careful When they take the knife! Underneath their fine incisions Stirs the Culprit -- Life! Those poignant words by the reclusive poet Emily Dickinson set the tone for this eloquent collection of stories, poems and essays, which reveal a side of medicine too often shoved aside by the intrusion of technology and coldly managed health care. For here, in the observations of a diverse group of physician and nonphysician writers -- like Chekhov, Hemingway, Pablo Neruda, Oliver Wendell Holmes, Eudora Welty, Dylan Thomas and Kurt Vonnegut -- the relationship between humanity and medicine emerges.

headline.main: Literature and Medicine Meet in Story Collection

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of health psychologists from Ohio University has found that giving first-time blood donors 3-D headsets that allow them to watch movies reduces the nausea, dizziness and lightheadedness that donors often report. Writing in the current issue of Psychosomatic Medicine, Dr. Christopher France and his colleagues reported that subjects allowed to see scenes of Paris, skiing and other subjects, accompanied by upbeat music, fared better than those who did not.

headline.main: Diversions Work for Some Blood Donors

docs.abstract: Ohio University health psychologists find giving first-time blood donors 3-D headsets that lets them watch movies reduces nausea, dizziness and lightheadedness that donors often report; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since 1997, when the Food and Drug Administration clarified its rules on advertising prescription drugs, pharmaceutical advertisements on television and in print have increased significantly. Gale Scott spoke to two doctors about how the advertising affects patients. Following are edited excerpts from those interviews. NO. These ads are helpful because they inform consumers. An educated patient is an easier patient to treat. In the world of health care, ignorance is not bliss. Other than the time and place of your own death, what things are we better off not knowing?
docs.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Dr Richard Dolimar, holds holds advertisements for prescription drugs are not confusing patients; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Are Your Parents Driving You Crazy?'' by Dr. Joseph A. Ilardo and Dr. Carole R. Rothman, VanderWyck & Burnham, $14.95 Your 82-year-old father wants to marry a woman he's just met. Your brother and sister won't offer to help take care of your parents, and maybe even discourage your own involvement. Your mother can't manage her checking account any longer but refuses your help. Your father wants to move in but your spouse says no.

headline.main: Addressing Problems That Confront Aging Parents

docs.lead_paragraph: Baby boys with twin sisters tend to weigh more at birth than their sisters, and also more than twins who are both male. One reason seems to be that having a female twin somehow prolongs the pregnancy, and as a result the boys weigh more at birth than boys born alone or with twin brothers.

headline.main: A Male's Advantage From the Start

docs.abstract: Dr Ruth Loos and colleagues from Center for Human Genetics find boys with twin sisters tend to weigh more at birth than their sisters and than boys born alone or with twin brothers; note having female twin somehow prolongs pregnancy (S)
